title: Cowboys owner Jerry Jones jokes about Jason Garrett's 'abusive language' penalty: 'We should all have stopped the wheel'
text:
CLOSE Check out some early NFL game headlines. USA TODAY

ARLINGTON, Texas — Jerry Jones hoped NFL official Scott Edwards wasn’t too upset.

The referee penalized Cowboys coach Jason Garrett toward the end of the third quarter for unsportsmanlike conduct, his colleague saying after the game that Garrett used “abusive language toward an official” while throwing a flag.

Abusive language?

“I hope the little darlin’ didn’t hear something he hadn’t heard before,” Cowboys owner Jerry Jones said after the Packers' 34-24 win. “We should all have stopped the wheel over there if he got [upset] over abusive language.”

Jones’ tongue-in-cheke remark characterized the team’s reaction to a penalty enforced on an important play in Dallas’ comeback effort.

Dallas trailed 31-10 with 19 seconds to play in the third quarter. Prescott found star receiver Amari Cooper 27 yards down the field with just enough time for Cooper to secure the ball and tap two feet in bounds before stepping past the sideline, cornerback Jaire Alexander inches away.

Here's Amari Cooper with the unreal catch that was overturned after being ruled incomplete.



And Jason Garrett getting the "Oh he hurt the ref who was wrong feelings" unsportsmanlike penalty pic.twitter.com/6L93Ft4aeL — Tom Downey (@WhatGoingDowney) October 6, 2019

The officials ruled the pass incomplete.

Garrett hurled his challenge flag to the ground, he and offensive coordinator Kellen Moore animated as they reacted to a play they felt was obviously a completion. On Fox’s broadcast, ex-Cowboys quarterback Troy Aikman was surprised.

“I’ve known Jason Garrett a long time and that’s not how he conducts himself,” said Aikman, whom Garrett once backed up. “I know that’s what’s so maddening right now for him to draw that penalty.”

Garrett broke down his challenge after the game.

“Obviously on that play, we had a great view of it and they called it an incompletion, so it was such a big play in the game, you have to use your flag there … to get the call correct,” Garrett said. “I knew we were going to have to use it again to correct the error.

“Apparently he didn’t like how I threw the flag.”

More: 32 things we learned from Week 5 of the 2019 NFL season

Official Ron Tolbert told a pool reporter after the game that Garrett’s language, not the flag throw, warranted the 15-yard penalty enforced on an otherwise 27-yard gain.

“Obviously,” Garrett said, “I didn’t handle the situation as well as I should have.”

His players could not have handled the accompanying penalty yards much better.

Facing first-and-25, Prescott completed a pass 27 yards deep left to running back Ezekiel Elliott as time expired in the third quarter. He hit Tavon Austin and tight end Jason Witten on the two next plays for 13 yards a piece. Prescott lucked out with a false start that negated a fumble by him and two defensive penalties that negated an end zone interception on a pass intended for Randall Cobb. The Cowboys capitalized on the Packers' mistakes as Elliott punched in a 2-yard score to narrow what earlier had been a 28-point deficit to 14.

Prescott lauded his teammates’ response but said he wouldn’t speak much on the penalty his coach incurred.

“We’ve got our coach’s back,” Prescott said. “I don’t want to say too much on that. That’s a guy being passionate about his team, passionate about the play. All I saw was him, ‘Hey, here’s the challenge flag. I know that’s a catch.’ A flag comes after that.

“I’ve just got to be careful what I say.”

Elliott said even though the officials “weren’t perfect” and “weren’t great,” he doesn’t believe they shoulder any share of blame for the outcome of the game.

“Honestly, just don’t ask me about any officiating questions,” Elliott said after posting 91 total yards and a touchdown. “I’m never going to be the guy to go out there and be like, ‘Hey, we lost because of the refs.’

“At the end of the day, we’ve got to look in the mirror as a team and realize that we shot ourselves in the foot too many times.”

description: Jason Garrett was penalized for a rare outburst in Sunday's loss to the Packers, a move that took many on the Cowboys by surprise.
